results.headline: My Best Friend’s Big Fat (Shouldn’t Happen) Scottish Wedding
results.summary_short: The romantic comedy “Made of Honor” adds tart satirical flavors to a cotton-candy formula without sabotaging the sugar rush.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Made of Honor

results.headline: In a Chokehold, on the Mat and in Life
results.summary_short: “Redbelt” is a satisfying, unexpectedly involving B-movie that owes as much to old Hollywood as to Greek tragedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Redbelt

results.headline: India Today: Big Visuals and Tiny Bikini
results.summary_short: With the arrival of the comically exuberant action-adventure-romance “Tashan” in theaters on Friday, the Great Bollywood Bikini Question of ’08 — will she or won’t she wear one? — was finally answered. Readers, she did.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tashan

results.headline: A Visit to Old China, Before It Drowns
results.summary_short: “Up the Yangtze” is an astonishing documentary of culture clash and the erasure of history amid China’s economic miracle.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Up the Yangtze

results.headline: Getting to Graffiti Art’s Roots
results.summary_short: “Bomb It” takes a comprehensively international viewpoint on graffiti culture.

results.headline: The Scenery’s Gorgeous. You Want a Plot, Too?
results.summary_short: Claude Lelouch’s “Roman de Gare” is a thriller, a murder mystery and a somewhat self-conscious literary puzzle.

results.headline: The Biological Clock Is Ticking, the Cause for Much Alarm
results.summary_short: “Then She Found Me,” a serious comedy, is more impressive for what it refuses to do than for its modest accomplishment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Then She Found Me

results.headline: A Sliver of Thrills
results.summary_short: A would-be erotic thriller with no heat and zero chills, “Deception” has a kind of glassy, glossy sheen and risible story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deception

results.headline: We, the People Behind the Abuse
results.summary_short: A blockbuster of a documentary, Errol Morris’s “Standard Operating Procedure” is an inquiry into the prisoner abuse scandal at Abu Ghraib.

results.headline: Two Buddies, Several Tokes Over the Line
results.summary_short: If you think the last seven years have been one long, dumb, dirty joke, then “Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay,” might be the perfect movie for you.

results.headline: An Extravagant Ruler of a Modest Kingdom
results.summary_short: Leaning more toward understanding than blame, “Without the King” examines a country forced to choose between tradition and survival.

results.headline: Learning on the Job About Birthing Babies
results.summary_short: The new comedy “Baby Mama” never comes fully to term, as it were.

results.headline: Beware the Road of Good Intentions
results.summary_short: Though it is suspenseful, unnerving and agile in its techniques, “Stuff and Dough” has more than speed and danger on its mind.

results.headline: When Love of Religion Leads to Hatred of Others
results.summary_short: “Constantine’s Sword” asks: When your core beliefs conflict with church doctrine, how far should your loyalty to the church extend?

results.headline: Life in the Japanese Mafia
results.summary_short: Jean-Pierre Limosin’s “Young Yakuza” looks at Japan’s version of the Mafia.

results.headline: The Allure of Psychological Damage
results.summary_short: A women-behind-bars plot seething with lesbianism, incest, hanging and catfights — on paper, at least, “Four Minutes” promises more fun than a Roger Corman marathon.

results.headline: Clues to the Killings May Be Optical Illusions
results.summary_short: The serial killer in “Anamorph” shows promise, even if some of his best moves are derivative.

results.headline: Taking It All Off
results.summary_short: Those excited by the words “Zombie Strippers” alone won’t be disappointed by Jay Lee’s unabashedly schlocky film, which he wrote, directed, shot and edited.

results.headline: Looking for a Terrorist, but Not Too Hard
results.summary_short: “Where in the World Is Osama bin Laden?” is not so much a documentary as the movie equivalent of a nonfiction stunt book.
